Can you translate the Greek text "Θαύμα έγινε που δεν σε άφησα στον τόπο, παλιοκερατά." into English? For context, the Greek multi-word expression "αφήνω στον τόπο κάποιον" can mean "to knock someone off (only by hitting)" or "to kill someone (outright) (general)".
Answer:
"It's a wonder I didn't leave you on the spot, old horned one." Here, the phrase "leave you on the spot" is used metaphorically to mean "knock you out" or even "kill you". The term "old horned one" is likely to be a localised or context-specific insult or nickname.

Can you translate the Greek text "Μια από τις αμέτρητες στιγμές σε ταινίες του Σταθαρου που άφησα τα κόκαλα μου από το γελιο!" into English? For context, the Greek multi-word expression "αφήνω τα κόκκαλά μου" can mean "to go the way of all flesh (to die/lose one's life somewhere (in a location)

the emphasis is often on the place)" or "to take a dirt nap".
Answer:
"One of the countless moments in Statharou's movies that had me in stitches from laughter!" Please note that "άφησα τα κόκαλα μου από το γέλιο" in this context is translated as "had me in stitches from laughter." It is a colloquial idiom indicating that the person laughed excessively hard, to the point of exhaustion or pain, not that they actually died.

"Did you drink the silent water?" would be a literal translation. However, considering the idiom, a more appropriate translation might be "Have you clammed up?" or "Has the cat got your tongue?"

The Greek text "έχει πάρει ψηλά τον αμανέ" translates to "he/she has put on airs" or "it has gone to his/her head" in English.

Answer:
The expression's literal and figurative interpretations have to be considered for a nuanced translation. Here's my attempt:

"I will wear my hat askew // And hang my jacket on my shoulder // There will come nights of pain and drinking // But I won't lose the journey of my life."

This translation may not capture all the implicit connotations. A more figurative rendering that incorporates the idiomatic sense of "wearing my hat askew" could be:

"I will show indifference // And bear the weight on my shoulder // There will come nights of enduring pain and drowning in liquor // But I won't forfeit the journey of my life."

Answer:
The Greek text "τα μυαλά τά 'χει πάνω από το κεφάλι του" translates to English as "he has his mind above his head". Depending on the context, it could mean he is either not focused/ daydreaming (i.e., has his head in the clouds) or he is acting in a foolish or silly manner (i.e., he is slap-happy).

For context, the Greek multi-word expression "πάω στη βρύση και δεν πίνω νερό" can mean "to be always a bridesmaid, never a bride (to almost reach one's goal but at the last time fail to reap the rewards of it)".
Answer:
"So, Olympiakos who went to the fountain but didn't drink water in Italy because Juventus drowned him in just two minutes..." This is a metaphorical way of saying that the team Olympiakos almost attained their goal in a match or competition in Italy, but Juventus defeated them at the last minute.
Prompt:
Can you translate the Greek text "Μας χρεώνουν ότι «πήγαμε στην βρύση και πάλι νερό δεν ήπιαμε», και όμως ήπιαμε και μάλιστα πολύ." into English? For context, the Greek multi-word expression "πάω στη βρύση και δεν πίνω νερό" can mean "to be always a bridesmaid, never a bride (to almost reach one's goal but at the last time fail to reap the rewards of it)".
Answer:
"They charge us that 'we went to the fountain but didn’t drink the water', yet we did drink, and indeed a lot." For context, the Greek expression is similar to 'always the bridesmaid, never the bride,' implying achieving a goal but not reaping its rewards.

For context, the Greek multi-word expression "πάω στη βρύση και δεν πίνω νερό" can mean "to be always a bridesmaid, never a bride (to almost reach one's goal but at the last time fail to reap the rewards of it)".
Answer:
"So Olympiacos, who went to the fountain but did not drink water in Italy because Juventus throttled him within two minutes..." The metaphor "went to the fountain but did not drink water" represents the fact that Olympiacos went close to achieving their goal but ultimately failed.

Answer:
"We are for tying up! It's true!" Please note that this is a literal translation. The phrase "Είμαστε για δέσιμο" is often used colloquially to mean "We are crazy" or "We are out of control". The added context phrase typically means "we are crazy enough to be locked up". The expression makes more sense in Greek culture and it can lose significance when it is translated literally. Also, the text could be translated idiomaticaly as "We are certifiable! It's true!"

"What are you going to eat, what are you going to eat? You're going to eat fear because the diet demands a spoonful of oil soup in a barrel of organic lettuce, please." Note that the text carries a humorous and sarcasticaly tone because of the exaggerated phrasing about the scarcity of food (a single spoonful of soup for a whole barrel of lettuce) and the hyperbole of "eating fear".

Answer:

Answer:

Prompt:
Can you translate the Greek text "Ρούπι δεν το κούνησα!" into English? For context, the Greek multi-word expression "δεν το κουνάω ρούπι" or "δεν το κουνάω" can mean "I don't leave for no reason".
Answer:
The translation would be "I didn't budge an inch!" It's a colloquial expression meaning that the speaker didn't move at all, regardless of the situation. The literal translation, working with your given context, would be something like "I didn't move even a rupee!" (Rupee also refers to an old Greek coin.) However, it's more about immobility or refusal to go somewhere/away.

Can you translate the Greek text "αφήστε τα παραμύθια και κάντε κυβέρνηση" into English? For context, the Greek multi-word expression "άσε το παραμύθι" can mean "cut the bullshit".
Answer:
The English translation would be "Drop the fairy tales and govern." The phrase implies frustration with false promises or excuses, and asks for action and responsibility instead.

"Unknowns made a mess at Makario Stadium"
Prompt:
Can you translate the Greek text "Τα έκανε πάλι γυαλιά καρφιά!" into English? For context, the Greek multi-word expression "τα κάνω γυαλιά καρφιά σε κάποιον " or "του τα κάνω γυαλιά καρφιά" can mean "to destroy everything".
Answer:
"He made a complete mess of it again!" or "He completely messed things up again!" This captures the sense of destruction implied by the Greek phrase. Your literal interpretation of "turn everything into glass and nails" doesn't have a direct equivalent in English, hence the softer translation.

The phrase "Θα μείνουν στον τόπο τα ζαβά" could be translated as "The bravado will drop dead" or more loosely as "The bravado will end right there". Here the word "ζαβά" refers to empty talk or boastfulness (bravado).

Answer:

Prompt:
Can you translate the Greek text "αρχιζω τα μα μου σου του" into English? For context, the Greek multi-word expression "αρχίζω τα μα και τα μου σε κάποιον" or "του αρχίζω τα μα και τα μου" can mean "to have objects for something, to growl".
Answer:
The exact direct translation of the Greek phrase "αρχιζω τα μα μου σου του" into English would be "I begin my, your, his/her mumblings" but it's an idiomatic saying, not meant to be translated literally. In practical terms, it usually means "I start complaining or grumbling about something to someone." This phrase is often used to describe a situation where someone starts expressing his/her dissatisfaction or disapproval about something strongly. Please note idiomatic sayings often can't be translated directly, and the meaning can vary by context.

Prompt:
Can you translate the Greek text "Βγες στη πιάτσα να βγάλεις μεροκάματο καρεκλάτε." into English? For context, the Greek multi-word expression "βγαίνω στην πιάτσα" can mean "to become active professionally and socially

in particular for paid sex,  to prostitute oneself".
Answer:
"Get out on the beat to make your daily earnings, hustle." 

It should be noted that this translation is a bit colloquial. With the context you provided, the phrase may imply sex work, but the literal translation does not categorically express this. "Seat" (καρέκλα) refers to 'work for someone' or 'job' in Greek slang. "-te" at the end is an intensive suffix that means 'a lot' or 'excessively'. The original phrase could be interpreted differently based on context.

The 81-year-old driver got into the driver’s seat and, possibly due to a handling error, instead of engaging the reverse gear, he shifted to the first gear. Answer:

Note: This translation maintains the informal and slang-ridden nature of the original Greek sentence. ""Ρε πούστη μου"" is literally "my fag," but it is used here in an affectionate and joking manner, so it was translated as "my dude." "Μωρέ δεν γαμιέστε" is literally "you don't fuck," but it is used here to mean "you don't understand/get it," so it was translated as such. This translation may vary depending on the dialect and other underlying contextual nuances.

"The bachelor gave the rose to the object of his desire, but in the end, he was left high and dry."

Answer:
"It is so as not to offend the sacred and holy of the Greek, one becomes furious (like a Turk)".

Please note, the phrase "γίνομαι Τούρκος" (becoming a Turk) here is used idiomatically in a culturally specific manner, as explained in your context. 'Becoming a Turk' is not meant literally - for Greeks, it has historically symbolized someone losing their temper due to the tense historical relationship between the two countries.

For context, the Greek multi-word expression "κατεβάζω τα ρολά" or "κατεβάζω ρολά" can mean "(for football teams) to play great defense".
Answer:
"They pulled down the shutters! 
With goalkeepers Zivko Zivkovic and Zeljko Brkic as the major protagonists, who didn't allow their opponents to score, Xanthi and PAOK remained at 0-0 in a friendly match."

Answer:
"Surely, as he himself has admitted, his rejections towards Tottenham so far have been his greatest collective appearance.

And how can he not say so? He pulled down the shutters that day!"

Can you translate the Greek text "Βρέθηκε τερματοφύλακας που κατέβασε κυριολεκτικά τα ρολά" into English? For context, the Greek multi-word expression "κατεβάζω τα ρολά" or "κατεβάζω ρολά" can mean "(for football teams) to play great defense".
Answer:
"A goalkeeper was found who literally pulled down the shutters" would be a literal translation.

A more idiomatic translation might be: "A goalkeeper was found who (truly/absolutely) excelled at defense."

Can you translate the Greek text "Α ναι! Δεν είμαστε τέτοια εποχή για εγκεφαλικά. Μην ξεχνάς πως Υπουργός Υγείας είναι ο Μπουμπούκος. Θες να πάω στα θυμαράκια, μάνα μου;" into English? For context, the Greek multi-word expression "πάω στα θυμαράκια" can mean "to go west".
Answer:
"Oh yes! This is not the time for strokes. Don't forget that Bouboukos is the Minister of Health. Do you want me to kick the bucket, my mother?" 

Note: "πάω στα θυμαράκια" is not exactly translated as "to go west" in modern English. This phrase in English comes from cowboy movies and implies dying or being killed. The Greek phrase's literal meaning is "to go to the little thyme plants" and is a euphemism for dying. So, "Do you want me to kick the bucket..." corresponds more closely to that Greek idiom, in terms of both familiarity and register.

Prompt:
Can you translate the Greek text "Ή -αν έχω άκρη- σβήνω την κλήση…" into English? For context, the Greek multi-word expression "σβήνω τη κλήση σε κάποιον" or "του σβήνω τη κλήση" can mean "erase traffic ticket".
Answer:
The literal translation of "Ή -αν έχω άκρη- σβήνω την κλήση…" would be "Or -if I have influence- I erase the call..." However, considering the given context, it might more accurately translate to "Or -if I have connections- I cancel the ticket..." Please note that this is a rough translation and may vary based on the full context of the conversation or text.

Can you translate the Greek text "Τώρα για να καταφέρουν να αναπληρώσουν αυτή την τεράστια έλλειψη και να μη γίνουν σαν τον όσιο Ονούφριο χρειάζονται 2 πράγματα: Μυαλό και (πολλά) λεφτά." into English? For context, the Greek multi-word expression "γίνομαι σαν τον 'Αγιο Ονούφριο" can mean "grow skinny".
Answer:
"Now, in order to compensate for this huge deficit and not become like the saint Onuphrius (grow skinny), they need two things: brains and (a lot of) money."
Prompt:

Answer:
"You have truly become like Saint Onuphrius." In the given context, it implies "You have really grown skinny."
Prompt:

Prompt:
Can you translate the Greek text "Και να λέει "όχι εμένα που θέλει να μου δόσει ο γιατρός φάρμακα για το μυαλό, βρε εγω έχω μυαλό ξουράφι" πως φτάσαμε από τη φύρα στο ξουράφι δεν κατάλαβα." into English? For context, the Greek multi-word expression "έχω μυαλό ξουράφι" or "έχω μυαλό" can mean "to be smart" or "to be shrewd".
Answer:
"And he is saying 'It's me the doctor wants to give mind medicine to, well, I am sharp-minded', I don't understand how we went from the marrow to the brain." Please note that the English translation tries to convey the essence of the saying "μυαλό ξουράφι", for which there is no direct equivalent in English. The term "marrow" is used to reflect the meaning of "ξουράφι", which refers to the sharpened end of a spatula used traditionally by shepherds to extract marrow from bones.

(I'm dying, I'm lost, I'm going to the Lord)

-Hello, my dear Trifyllara!
- Are you referring to Platanias?"

Prompt:
Can you translate the Greek text "Γιατι τον πεθαμενο τον πανε τεσσερις ... Γιατί δεν μπορεί να πάει μόνος του!" into English? For context, the Greek multi-word expression "τον πάνε τέσσερις" can mean "to die".
Answer:
"Why do four people carry the dead... Because he cannot go alone!" This Greek phrase is somewhat idiomatic, and expresses the fact that when someone dies, he/she can't go to their final resting place alone, hence, typically in a funeral, four individuals (pallbearers) carry the coffin.

Prompt:
Can you translate the Greek text "Όταν, όμως,  προσπαθούμε  να απομακρύνουμε από το σύγχρονο, δημοκρατικό Κράτος μας, την Εκκλησία  – και να την περιορίσουμε στα παράξενα, «όσια» και «ιερά» μυστήρια της – ερχόμαστε αντιμέτωποι με αφορισμούς, κατάρες και στριγγλίσιες κραυγές, ωσάν να κόβουμε την αναπνοή στους παπάδες – και των ομοούσιων και ομοιουσίων αυτών." into English? For context, the Greek multi-word expression "κόβω την αναπνοή σε κάποιον" or "κόβω την αναπνοή κάποιου" or "του κόβω την αναπνοή" can mean "leave sb breathless (metaphorically)".
Answer:
"However, when we try to distance the Church from our modern, democratic State - and limit it to its odd, 'holy,' and 'sacred' mysteries - we face excommunications, curses, and shrill cries, as if we're leaving the priests - and their consubstantial and homoousian counterparts - breathless." 

Note: "consubstantial" and "homoousian" are technical terms used in theology to describe the relationship among the three persons (Father, Son, and Holy Spirit) in the Christian concept of the Trinity. They mean 'of the same substance,' with "homoousian" being the Greek term translated as "consubstantial" in English.

Answer:
